And whenever the burdens of the worldly life (Dunya) lighten from the Heart (Qalb), the manifestation of meaning draws near within it. So the Heart (Qalb) is like a mirror, and the desires (Shahawat) are like rust, and the meanings of the Quran are like the images that appear in the mirror. And the spiritual training (Riyadah) of the Heart (Qalb) by removing the desires (Shahawat) is like polishing the clarity for the mirror. And for that reason, the Prophet (peace be upon him) said: 'When my nation magnifies the Dinar and Dirham, the awe of Islam is stripped from them, and when they abandon commanding the good (Ma'ruf) and forbidding the evil (Munkar), they are deprived of the blessing of revelation.' Al-Fudayl said, meaning they are deprived of understanding the Quran. And Allah, the Exalted and Majestic, has made Turning (Inabah) a condition for understanding and reminding, for He, the Exalted, said: 'As an insight (Tabsirah) and a Remembrance (Dhikr) for every turning servant (Abd Munib).' And He, the Exalted and Majestic, said: 'And none will be reminded except he who turns (Yanib).' And He, the Exalted, said: 'Only those of understanding (Ulul-Albab) are reminded.' So the one who prefers the deception of the worldly life (Dunya) over the bliss of the Hereafter (Akhirah) is not among those of understanding (Dhawil-Albab), and for that reason, the secrets of the Book are not unveiled to him.

ğŸ“– Vol 4: Poverty and Abstinence
And know that asceticism (Zuhd) is a degree that is the perfection of the righteous (Al-Abrar) and the possessor of this state is from the near ones (Al-Muqarrabin), so it is no wonder that asceticism becomes a deficiency in his right, for the good deeds of the righteous are the sins of the near ones. This is because the one who hates the worldly life (Al-Dunya) is preoccupied with the worldly life, just as the one who desires it is preoccupied with it, and preoccupation with other than Allah the Exalted is a veil (Hijab) from Allah the Exalted, for there is no distance between you and Allah the Exalted such that distance would be a veil. For He is closer to you than the jugular vein (Hablu Al-Warid), and He is not in a place such that the heavens and the earth would be a veil between you and Him. So there is no veil between you and Him except your preoccupation with other than Him, and your preoccupation with your soul (Nafs) and its desires is preoccupation with other than Him. And you remain preoccupied with your soul and the desires of your soul, so likewise you remain veiled from Him. So the one preoccupied with love of his soul is preoccupied from Allah the Exalted, and the one preoccupied with hatred of his soul is also preoccupied from Allah the Exalted with everything other than Allah. Its example is like the example of a watcher present in a gathering that brings together the lover (Al-Ashiq) and the beloved (Al-Ma'shuq). If the heart (Qalb) of the lover turns to the watcher and to hatred of him, finding him burdensome, and disliking his presence, then he is in a state where his heart is preoccupied with hatred of him, diverted from delighting in witnessing his beloved. And if love (Al-Ishq) had completely absorbed him, he would have been heedless of other than the beloved and would not have turned to him. So just as looking to other than the beloved out of love for him when the lover is present is association (Shirk) in love and a deficiency in it, likewise looking to other than the Beloved out of hatred for him is association in it and a deficiency, but one of them is lighter than the other. Rather, perfection is that the heart does not turn to other than the Beloved with hatred or love, for just as two loves do not gather in the heart in one state, so also hatred and love do not gather in one state. So the one preoccupied with hatred of the worldly life is heedless of Allah like the one preoccupied with love of it, except that the one preoccupied with love of it is heedless and in his heedlessness is traveling the path of distance, and the one preoccupied with hatred of it is heedless.

Knowledge is not attained except through humility and listening attentively. Allah the Exalted said: 'Indeed in that is a Remembrance (Dhikr) for whoever has a Heart (Qalb) or listens attentively while he is witnessing' (Qaf: 37). Then, the ability to understand does not assist him until he listens attentively while he is witnessing, present of Heart (Qalb), to receive everything that is imparted to him with good listening, supplication, gratitude, joy, and acceptance of favor. So let the student be to his teacher like fertile land that received abundant rain, so all its parts drank it and submitted completely to accepting it. And whenever the teacher indicates to him a path in learning, let him follow it and abandon his own opinion, for the error of his guide is more beneficial to him than his own correctness in himself, since experience reveals subtleties whose hearing is astonishing, while its benefit is great.

And as for the Signs (Ayat) of Allah in His earth, then in witnessing them are benefits for the insightful. In them are adjacent regions, and in them are mountains, deserts, seas, and types of animals and plants. And there is not a thing from them except that it is a witness for Allah to Oneness (al-Wahdaniyah) and glorifying Him with a fluent tongue that none perceives except he who casts the hearing (al-Sam') and he is a witness (Shahid). And as for the deniers, the heedless, and those deceived by the glittering mirage from the bloom of the worldly life (al-Dunya), then they do not see nor hear because they are isolated from the hearing (al-Sam') and veiled from the Signs (Ayat) of their Lord. They know an outward aspect from the life of the worldly life (al-Dunya), and they from the Hereafter (al-Akhirah) are heedless. And what is intended by the hearing (al-Sam') is not the outward hearing (al-Sam' al-Zahir), for those intended by it were not isolated from it. Rather, what is intended by it is the inward hearing (al-Sam' al-Batin). And with the outward hearing (al-Sam' al-Zahir) only sounds are perceived, and in it man shares with all other animals. As for the inward hearing (al-Sam' al-Batin), then with it is perceived the tongue of the state (Lisan al-Hal) which is an utterance beyond the utterance of speech (al-Maqal). It resembles the saying of the speaker narrating the speech of the peg and the wall: The wall said to the peg: Why do you split me? So it said: Ask the one who hammers me and did not leave behind me the stone that is behind me. And there is not an atom in the heavens and the earth except that it has types of witnesses for Allah the Exalted to Oneness (al-Wahdaniyah) which are its declaration of Oneness (Tawhid), and types of witnesses for its Maker to Holiness (al-Taqdis) which are its glorification (Tasbih). But they do not comprehend its glorification (Tasbih) because they have not journeyed from the narrowness of the outward hearing (al-Sam' al-Zahir) to the expanse of the inward hearing (al-Sam' al-Batin), and from the weakness of the tongue of speech (Lisan al-Maqal) to the eloquence of the tongue of the state (Lisan al-Hal). And if every incapable one were capable of such a journey, Solomon (peace be upon him) would not have been uniquely distinguished with understanding the speech of the birds, and Moses (peace be upon him) would not have been uniquely distinguished with hearing the speech of Allah the Exalted which must be sanctified from resemblance to letters.

If you are not among its people, then look at the address of Allah the Exalted to His Messenger and take it by the light of faith. Indeed, Allah the Exalted said to the closest of His worshipers to Him and the highest of them in degree with Him: 'Indeed, for you in the daytime is prolonged glorification, and remember the name of your Lord and devote yourself to Him with complete devotion' (Quran 73:7-8). And He the Exalted said: 'And remember the name of your Lord morning and evening, and during the night prostrate to Him and glorify Him a long night' (Quran 76:25-26). And He the Exalted said: 'And glorify with the praise of your Lord before the rising of the sun and before the setting, and during the night glorify Him and after the prostrations' (Quran 50:39-40). And He the Glorified said: 'And glorify with the praise of your Lord when you rise, and during the night glorify Him and after the stars' (Quran 52:48-49). And He the Exalted said: 'Indeed, the night prayer is more intense and more upright for recitation' (Quran 73:6). And He the Exalted said: 'And during the hours of the night glorify and at the ends of the day, that you may be pleased' (Quran 20:130). And He the Mighty and Majestic said: 'And establish prayer at the two ends of the day and at the approach of the night. Indeed, good deeds remove the evil deeds' (Quran 11:114). Then look how He described the successful among His servants and with what He described them. He the Exalted said: 'Is one who is devoutly obedient during periods of the night, prostrating and standing, fearing the Hereafter and hoping for the mercy of his Lord? Say, 'Are those who know equal to those who do not know?'' (Quran 39:9). And He the Exalted said: 'Their sides forsake their beds, calling upon their Lord in fear and hope' (Quran 32:16). And He the Mighty and Majestic said: 'And those who spend the night for their Lord prostrating and standing' (Quran 25:64). And He the Mighty and Majestic said: 'They used to sleep but little of the night, and in the hours before dawn they would ask forgiveness' (Quran 51:17-18). And He the Mighty and Majestic said: 'So exalted is Allah when you reach the evening and when you reach the morning' (Quran 30:17). And He the Exalted said: 'And do not drive away those who call upon their Lord morning and evening, desiring His countenance' (Quran 6:52). All of this clarifies for you that the path to the Exalted is the observance of times and filling them with regular devotions (Awrad) on the basis of continuity. Therefore, he (the Prophet) said: 'The most beloved of Allah's servants to Allah are those who observe the sun, the moon, and the shadows for the remembrance (Dhikr) of Allah the Exalted.'
